'''Tony Randall''' (born '''Aryeh (Arthur) Leonard Rosenberg'''; February 26, 1920{{spaced ndash}}May 17, 2004) was an [[Americans|American]] actor. He is best known for his role as Felix Unger in a [[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|television adaptation]] of the 1965 play ''[[The Odd Couple (play)|The Odd Couple]]'' by [[Neil Simon]].<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Severo |title=Tony Randall, 84, Dies; Fussbudget Felix in 'Odd Couple,' He Loved the Stage | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/19/theater/tony-randall-84-dies-fussbudget-felix-in-odd-couple-he-loved-the-stage.html?ref=tony_randall |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=19 May 2004 | accessdate=2010-10-21}}</ref><ref name=post>{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Shales |title=Tony Randall, Bright, Zestful And Always Endearing. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A38144-2004May18.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=10 May 2004 |accessdate=2008-04-26}}</ref>
In a career spanning about six decades, Randall received six [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations and six [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations (winning one). On the May 9, 1990 episode of "The Tonight Show," he added, “This is my 95th time on this show." ==Biography== ===Early years=== Randall was born to a [[Jewish]] family, in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]], [[Oklahoma]], the son of Julia (née Finston) and Mogscha Rosenberg, an art and antiques dealer.<ref>{{cite web | title=Tony Randall Biography | url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/79/Tony-Randall.html | work=filmreference | year=2008 | accessdate=2008-12-11}}</ref>
He attended [[Central High School (Tulsa, Oklahoma)|Tulsa Central High School]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Conner |first=Thomas |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/randall-s-dreams-of-acting-started-in-tulsa/article_838b6f2f-7d13-545f-a4b7-f07d2c027050.html |title=Randall's dreams of acting started in Tulsa |newspaper=[[Tulsa World]] |date=19 May 2004}}</ref>
Randall attended [[Northwestern University]] for a year before going to [[New York City]] to study at the [[Neighborhood Playhouse|Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre]]. He studied under [[Sanford Meisner]] and choreographer [[Martha Graham]]. Randall worked as an announcer at radio station [[WTAG]] in [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]], [[Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1941/1941-08-18-BC.pdf |title=Behind the Mike |journal=[[Broadcasting & Cable|Broadcasting]] |volume=21 |number=7 |page=39 |date=18 August 1941 |issn=1068-6827}}</ref> As '''Anthony Randall''', he starred with [[Jane Cowl]] in [[George Bernard Shaw]]'s ''[[Candida (play)|Candida]]'' and [[Ethel Barrymore]] in [[Emlyn Williams]]'s ''[[The Corn Is Green]]''.
Randall then served for four years with the [[United States Army Signal Corps]] in [[World War II]], refusing an entertainment assignment with Special Services. After the war, he worked at the [[Olney Theatre]] in [[Montgomery County, Maryland|Montgomery County]], [[Maryland]] before heading back to New York City.
In the 1940s, one of his first jobs was playing "Reggie" on the long-running radio series ''[[I Love a Mystery]]''.
===Broadway=== In 1946, Randall was cast as one of the brothers in a touring production of [[Katharine Cornell]]'s revival of ''[[The Barretts of Wimpole Street]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mosel |first=Tad |authorlink=Tad Mosel |title=Leading Lady: The World and Theatre of Katharine Cornell |publisher=[[Little, Brown and Company]] |year=1978 |isbn=0316585378}}</ref>
Randall then appeared on Broadway in Cornell's production of ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' (1947-48) alongside Cornell and a young [[Charlton Heston]] and [[Maureen Stapleton]].
He was in ''[[Caesar and Cleopatra (play)|Caesar and Cleopatra]]'' (1949-50) with [[Cedric Hardwicke]] and [[Lili Palmer]].
Randall also began appearing on television, notably episodes of ''[[One Man's Family]]''. ===''Mr Peepers''=== Tony Randall's first major television role was as a history teacher, Harvey Weskit, in ''[[Mister Peepers]]'' (1952–1955). He continued to guest star on other shows such as ''[[The Gulf Playhouse]]'' (directed by [[Arthur Penn]]), ''[[The Pepsi-Cola Playhouse]]'', ''[[Kraft Theatre]]'', ''[[The Motorola Television Hour]]'', ''[[Armstrong Circle Theatre]]'', ''[[Studio One in Hollywood]]'', ''[[Appointment with Adventure]]'', and ''[[The Philco-Goodyear Television Playhouse]]''.
Randall replaced [[Gig Young]] in the Broadway hit ''[[Oh, Men! Oh, Women!]]'' (1954). ===''Inherit the Wind''=== Randall's first major role in a Broadway hit was in ''[[Inherit the Wind (play)|Inherit the Wind]]'' (1955-57) portraying Newspaperman E. K. Hornbeck (based on real life cynic [[H. L. Mencken]]), alongside [[Ed Begley]] and [[Paul Muni]].
On television he was in ''[[Heaven Will Protect the Working Girl]]'' (1956) co-written by Neil Simon. He guest starred on ''[[The Alcoa Hour]]'', ===Film Star=== Randall's success in ''Inherit the Wind'' lead to film offers and his first significant big-screen role in ''[[Oh, Men! Oh, Women!]]'' (1957). It was made at [[20th Century Fox]] who promoted Randall to stardom with ''[[Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?]]'' (1957) alongside [[Jayne Mansfield]]. He had one of the leads in ''[[No Down Payment]]'' (1957).
In 1958, Randall played the leading role in the Broadway [[musical comedy]] ''[[Oh, Captain!]]'', taking on a role originated on film by [[Alec Guinness]]. ''Oh, Captain!'' was a financial failure, but Randall received a [[Tony Award]] nomination for his dance turn with prima ballerina [[Alexandra Danilova]].
Randall was in ''[[Westinghouse Desilu Playhouse]]'', ''[[Goodyear Theatre]]'', ''[[The United States Steel Hour]]'', ''[[Sunday Showcase]]'' and ''[[Playhouse 90]]''. ===Doris Day and Rock Hudson=== Randall co-starred with [[Debbie Reynolds]] in ''[[The Mating Game (film)|The Mating Game]]'' (1959) at MGM. He was in a huge hit with ''[[Pillow Talk (film)|Pillow Talk]]'' (1959) supporting [[Doris Day]] and [[Rock Hudson]].
He then starred in an NBC-TV special ''The Secret of Freedom'', which was filmed during the summer of 1959 in [[Mount Holly, New Jersey]], and broadcast on the network during the fall of 1959 and again in early 1960. On TV he was also in ''[[The Man in the Moon (1960 film)|The Man in the Moon]]'' (1960) co written by [[Mel Brooks]].
Randall was top billed in MGMs ''[[The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1960 film)|The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn]]'' (1960), then had a ''Pillow Talk'' style support role in ''[[Let's Make Love]]'' (1960) with [[Marilyn Monroe]] and [[Yves Montand]] and ''[[Lover Come Back (1961 film)|Lover Come Back]]'' (1961) with Hudson and Day.
Randall continued to guest on TV shows like ''[[General Electric Theater]]'', and ''[[Checkmate]]''. In 1961 Randall played a highly dramatic role in "Hangover," an episode of ''[[The Alfred Hitchcock Hour]]'' in which he portrayed an alcoholic business executive who strangles his wife in a drunken rage.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0394047/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1 "Hangover,"] ''The Alfred Hitchcock Hour'', S01E17, originally telecast December 6, 1962. International Movie Database (IMDb). Retrieved March 30, 2017.</ref>
He starred in a TV adaptation of ''[[Arsenic & Old Lace]]'' (1962), and had big screen leading roles in ''[[Boys' Night Out (film)|Boys' Night Out]]'' (1962), and ''[[Island of Love (1963 film)|Island of Love]]'' (1963).
Randall starred as nearly all of the leading characters in the 1964 classic film ''[[7 Faces of Dr. Lao]]'', which was based on ''[[The Circus of Dr. Lao]]'' by [[Charles G. Finney]]. The film received an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] for [[William J. Tuttle]]'s makeup artistry.
He had the lead in ''[[The Brass Bottle (1964 film)|The Brass Bottle]]'' (1964) and made one last film with Hudson and Day, ''[[Send Me No Flowers]]'' (1965).
Randall had the lead in ''[[Fluffy (1965 film)|Fluffy]]'' (1965), a comedy about a lion; '[[The Alphabet Murders]]'' (1965), playing [[Hercule Poirot]] for [[Frank Tashlin]]; ''[[Our Man in Marrakesh]]'' (1966), as a secret agent; and ''[[Hello Down There]]'' (1969).
Randall returned to Broadway in ''UTBU'' (1966) which only had a short run. He was in the TV movie ''[[The Littlest Angel]]'' (1969).
===''The Odd Couple''=== [[File:Tony Randall Jack Klugman Odd Couple 1972.JPG|thumb|Randall with Jack Klugman in a publicity photo of ''The Odd Couple'', 1972]] Randall returned to television in 1970 as Felix Unger in ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]]'', opposite [[Jack Klugman]], a role lasting for five years. The names of Felix's children on ''The Odd Couple'' were Edna and Leonard, named for Randall's sister and Randall himself.
In 1974, Randall and Jack Klugman appeared in television spots endorsing a ''[[Yahtzee]]'' spinoff, ''Challenge Yahtzee''. They appeared in character as Felix and Oscar, and the TV spots were filmed on the same set as ''The Odd Couple''.
During the series run he had a small role in ''[[Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* (*But Were Afraid to Ask) (film)|Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex * But Were Afraid to Ask]]'' (1972).
In 1973, he was originally hired to play the voice of Templeton the gluttonous rat in ''[[Charlotte's Web (1973 film)|Charlotte's Web]]'', but was replaced at the last minute by [[Paul Lynde]], due his voice sounding too sophisticated and the director wanting Templeton to have a [[nasal voice]]. ===''The Tony Randall Show'' === From 1976-78, he starred in ''[[The Tony Randall Show]]'', playing a Philadelphia judge. He had small roles in ''[[Kate Bliss and the Ticker Tape Kid]]'' (1978), ''[[Scavenger Hunt]]'' (1979), ''[[Foolin' Around]]'' (1980). ===''Love, Sidney''=== Randal starred in ''[[Love, Sidney]]'' from 1981-83. In the TV movie that served as the latter show's pilot, Sidney Shorr was written as a [[homosexuality|gay]] man, but his character's sexuality was made ambiguous when the series premiered. Randall refused to star in any more television shows, favoring the Broadway stage as his medium.
He did star in the TV movies ''[[Sunday Drive (film)|Sunday Drive]]'' (1986) for Disney, ''[[Save the Dog!]]'' (1988), ''[[The Man in the Brown Suit]]'' (1989). From October 30 to November 2, 1987, Randall hosted the [[free preview]] of [[HBO]]'s short-lived premium channel [[HBO#Festival|Festival]].<ref>Festival Free Preview Oct. 13–Nov. 2, 1987 promotional mailer</ref>
In 1989 he returned to Broadway as a replacement in ''[[M. Butterfly]]''.
===National Actors Theatre=== In 1991, Randall founded the [[National Actors Theatre]] (ultimately housed at [[Pace University]] in New York City. Their productions included ''[[The Crucible]]'' (1991), ''A Little Hotel on the Side'' (1992), ''The Master Builder'' (1992), ''The Seagull'' (1992), ''Saint Joan'' (1993), ''Three Men on a Horse'' (1993), ''Timon of Athens'' (1993), ''The Government Inspector'' (1993), ''The Flowering Peach'' (1994), ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'' (1994), ''The School for Scandal'' (1995), ''Inherit the Wind'' (1996), and ''The Gin Game'' (1997). He also did a production of ''The Sunshine Boys'' (1997) with Klugman which was a big success.
In September 1993, Randall and Jack Klugman reunited in the CBS-TV movie ''[[The Odd Couple: Together Again]]'' reprising their roles. The story began when, after Felix ruined plans for his daughter Edna's wedding, his wife Gloria threw him out of the house for 11 days, which left him no choice but to move back in with Oscar and to help him recover, getting him back in shape after throat cancer surgery left his voice very raspy. [[File:Tony Randall handprints.jpg|right|thumb|The hand prints of Tony Randall in front of [[The Great Movie Ride]] at [[Walt Disney World]]'s [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] theme park.]]
Randall's later stage productions included ''Night Must Fall'' (1999) and ''Judgment at Nuremberg'' (2001).
Periodically, he performed in stage revivals of ''[[The Odd Couple (play)|The Odd Couple]]'' with [[Jack Klugman]] including a stint in London in 1996. . Later film roles included ''[[Fatal Instinct]]'' (1994) and ''[[Down with Love]]'' (2003).
Randall's last appearances on stage as an actor were in ''The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui'' (2002) and ''Right You Are'' (2003). ===Guest appearances=== On September 4, 1955, Randall and Jack Klugman appeared together with [[Gena Rowlands]] in the episode "The Pirate's House" of the [[Columbia Broadcasting Company|CBS]] [[anthology series]], ''[[Appointment with Adventure]]''.
Randall was a frequent guest on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' and often spoke of his love of [[opera]], saying it was due in no small part to the salaciousness of many of the plotlines. He also admitted to sneaking tape recorders into operas to make his own private recordings. He chided [[Johnny Carson]] for his chain-smoking and was generally fastidious. At the time of his death, Randall had appeared as a guest on ''The Tonight Show'' 105 times, more often than any other celebrity.
Randall appeared frequently on ''[[What's My Line?]]'', ''[[Password (TV series)|Password]]'', ''[[The Hollywood Squares]]'', and the [[Pyramid (game show)|''$10,000'' and ''$20,000 Pyramids'']]. He also parodied his pompous image with an appearance as a "contestant" on ''[[The Gong Show]]'' in 1977.
First aired on October 11, 1980, Randall was a guest star on the 5th and final season of ''[[The Muppet Show]]''. This was the 100th episode of the show.
Randall, along with [[John Goodman]] and [[Drew Barrymore]], was one of the first guests on the debut episode of ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' on September 13, 1993. He would also appear in [[Conan O'Brien|Conan's]] ''5th Anniversary Special'' with the character PimpBot 5000. Randall was a frequent guest as well on both of [[David Letterman]]'s late-night shows ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' and the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', making 70 appearances, according to his obituary in the ''[[Washington Post]]''; Letterman said that Randall was one of his favorite guests, along with [[Regis Philbin]].
On November 7, 1994, Randall appeared on the game show ''[[Jeopardy!]]'', as part of a Special Edition Celebrity ''Jeopardy!'' episode playing on behalf of the National Actors Theatre. He came in second place after [[Norman Schwarzkopf, Jr.|General Norman Schwarzkopf, Jr.]] and before Actress [[Stefanie Powers]], with a final score of $9,900.<ref>{{cite web | title=J! Archive | url=http://www.j-archive.com/showplayer.php?player_id=6962 | accessdate=2011-10-03}}</ref>
===Other creative activities=== In 1973, Tony Randall and Jack Klugman recorded an album called ''The Odd Couple Sings'' for London Records. Roland Shaw and The London Festival Orchestra and Chorus provided the music and additional vocals.<ref>{{AllMusic | class= album |id = r63924 | tab = | label=The Odd Couple Sings | first= Jason | last=Ankeny | accessdate= 2011/12/20}}</ref> The record was not a chart-topper but is a highly sought-after item for many ''Odd Couple'' fans.<ref>[[WLNY-TV]]. The Odd Couple marathon. January 1, 2013</ref> Randall and Klugman also collaborated for a series of television commercials for Eagle Brand snacks, which can be viewed on youtube.
A noted [[Storytelling|raconteur]], Randall co-wrote with Mike Mindlin a collection of amusing and sometimes racy show business anecdotes called ''Which Reminds Me'', published in 1989.
In keeping with his penchant for both championing and mocking the culture that he loved, during the [[Big Band]] era revival in the mid-1960s, he produced a record album of 1930s songs, ''Vo Vo De Oh Doe'', inspired by (and covering) [[The New Vaudeville Band]]'s one-hit wonder, "[[Winchester Cathedral (song)|Winchester Cathedral]]". He mimicked (and somewhat exaggerated) the [[vibrato]] style of [[Carmen Lombardo]], and the two of them once sang a duet of Lombardo's signature song "Boo Hoo (You've Got Me Crying for You)" on ''[[The Tonight Show]]''.
===Activism=== Randall was an advocate for the arts. During the summer of 1980, he served as the celebrity host of the [[New York Philharmonic Orchestra]]'s concerts in [[Central Park]], [[New York City]].
He was politically liberal. During the [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 1972|U.S. presidential primaries]] in [[United States presidential election, 1972|1972]], he appeared as the [[Celebrity activists in George McGovern's 1972 presidential campaign|featured celebrity]] at numerous fundraising house-parties for [[George McGovern presidential campaign, 1972|Democratic candidate]] [[George McGovern]].<ref>[https://www.myspace.com/georgemcgovern/photos/772035#%7B%22ImageId%22%3A772035%7D Invitation letter for "Together for McGovern at the Garden, June 14, 1972" (producer: Warren Beatty)]</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Tony Randall best 800.jpg|thumb|Randall's headstone in [[Westchester Hills Cemetery]]]]
Randall was married to Florence Gibbs from 1938 until her death from cancer on April 18, 1992. The following year, he said, "I wish I believed I'd see my parents again, see my wife again. But I know it's not going to happen."<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=September 25, 2003 |title=Aging Actor Tony Randall Fantasizes About His Funeral}}</ref> He remarried on November 17, 1995, to Heather Harlan, an intern in one of his theatrical programs. At the time, Tony was 75 years old and Heather, 25. They lived in a Manhattan apartment and bought a vacation apartment in [[Key Biscayne, Florida]], in 2003. The couple, who had two children, Julia born on April 11 1997 and Jefferson born on June 15 1998, remained married until his death in May 2004.<ref name="claire2008">{{cite journal |url=http://www.marieclaire.com/sex-love/advice/a1123/tony-randall-wife/ |title=The Odd Couple |first=Judith |last=Newman |authorlink=Judith Newman |journal=[[Marie Claire]] |date=28 January 2008 |issn=0025-3049}}</ref>
In his book ''Which Reminds Me,'' Randall maintained that any publicity an actor generates should be about his work, not himself. "The public knows only one thing about me: I don't smoke."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P006ZhJSGMkC&dq=which+reminds+me&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=smoke|title=Which Reminds Me|last=Randall|first=Tony|last2=Mindlin|first2=Michael|publisher=Delacorte Press|year=1989|isbn=0-385-29785-8|location=New York|pages=143}}</ref>
==Death== Randall died in his sleep on May 17, 2004, at [[NYU Medical Center]] of [[pneumonia]] that he had contracted following [[coronary artery bypass surgery|coronary bypass surgery]] in December 2003. He had been hospitalized since the operation.<ref>{{cite news| title=Actor Tony Randall dies at age 84| url=http://www.today.com/popculture/actor-tony-randall-dies-age-84-wbna5004611| work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]| date=May 18, 2004| agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> His remains are interred at the [[Westchester Hills Cemetery]] in [[Hastings-on-Hudson]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref name=nytimes/><ref name=post/>

==Awards and honors== Randall was nominated for five [[Golden Globe]] awards and six [[Emmy Award]]s, winning one Emmy in 1975 for his work on the [[sitcom]] ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]]''. In 1993, he received [[The Hundred Year Association of New York]]'s Gold Medal Award "in recognition of outstanding contributions to the City of New York." [[Pace University]] granted him an honorary Doctor of Fine Arts degree in 2003. In 1999 the [[City College of New York]] honored Randall with the John H. Finley Award for outstanding service to the City of New York.
